title: Case Study: Diabetic Foot Ulcer in a 55-Year-Old Male
clinical_history: A 55-year-old male with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes presents with a non-healing ulcer on the plantar surface of his right foot. The patient reports that the ulcer started as a small blister 6 weeks ago and has gradually increased in size despite conservative treatment with topical antibiotics and dressings. He has a history of neuropathy and has experienced numbness and tingling in his feet for several years. The patient has been managing his diabetes with medication and diet but has struggled with adherence to his treatment plan.

nprs.affected_area: pain and tenderness at the ulcer site
burning sensation in the foot due to neuropathy

aggrevating_factors: prolonged standing, walking, or pressure on the affected foot
picture: a photograph of the patient's foot with the ulcer
past_history: history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetic nephropathy
medical_history: type 2 diabetes for 10 years, with complications including neuropathy and nephropathy
medications: metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and gabapentin for neuropathy
personal_history: married with two children, works as an accountant, and has a sedentary lifestyle
imaging: X-rays of the foot show no signs of osteomyelitis or Charcot changes, but MRI may be ordered to rule out deeper tissue involvement
